Rename the unzipped directory to the name you want to appear in the URL (for example, name it "wiki" if you want the URL http://example.com/wiki/).

steps.title: CHMOD the permission settings for the "config" subdirectory to 770, so that it is writable by the web server (Linux only).
steps.content: CHMOD the permission settings for the "config" subdirectory to 770, so that it is writable by the web server (Linux only).
Go to the directory in your web browser (e.g. http://localhost/wiki/).

steps.title: If you know the root password for your MySQL server, the MediaWiki setup script can automatically create a database and an account to access it.
steps.content: If you know the root password for your MySQL server, the MediaWiki setup script can automatically create a database and an account to access it. Skip to the "Run the installation script" section below.

steps.title: If you don't know the root password for your MySQL server, you need to create a MySQL database and a user before installing MediaWiki.
steps.content: If you don't know the root password for your MySQL server, you need to create a MySQL database and a user before installing MediaWiki. You can do this using various control panels such as phpMyAdmin . See the corresponding documentation. Most web hosting services provide a MySQL database along with your hosting account. If that is the case, use the MySQL credentials provided by your host along with the database name, and then specify something like "mw_" as table prefix. This will allow MediaWiki to tell what tables belong to it. Alternatively, ask your hosting service to create an account for, then proceed as above.
